In order to comply with new security policies, an administrator needs to prevent the SSH server from using insecure algorithms.
Which of the following files should be edited to accomplish this?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: A. /etc/ssh/sshd_config

ssh_config: configuration file for the ssh client on the host machine you are running. For example, if you want to ssh to another remote host machine, you use a SSH client. Every settings for this SSH client will be using ssh_config, such as port number, protocol version and encryption/MAC algorithms.

sshd_config: configuration file for the sshd daemon (the program that listens to any incoming connection request to the ssh port) on the host machine. That is to say, if someone wants to connect to your host machine via SSH, their SSH client settings must match your sshd_config settings in order to communicate with you, such as port number, version and so on.

questions.question_text: Which of the following configuration files should be modified to disable Ctrl+Alt+Del in Linux?

discussion.content:
[root@orac-rhel8 etc]# cat inittab

# inittab is no longer used.
#
# ADDING CONFIGURATION HERE WILL HAVE NO EFFECT ON YOUR SYSTEM.
#
# Ctrl-Alt-Delete is handled by /usr/lib/systemd/system/ctrl-alt-del.target

Correct Answer: A. /etc/inittab

To prevent the init process from handling Ctrl-Alt-Del, edit the file ‘/etc/inittab‘ comment the line which begins with ‘ca::ctrlaltdel:‘

For RHEL 5.X & CentOS 5.X
To prevent the init process from handling Ctrl-Alt-Del, edit the file ‘/etc/inittab‘

The clue here is "/bin/false" this will disable the user, what you need to do here is change /'bin/false, to' /'bin/bash". You can do this by typing "chsh -s /bin/bash username" or "usermod -s /bin/bash username"
useradd -s /nin/bash will add another user while the usermod will change the /bin/falsa to /bin/bash

A. usermod -s /bin/bash joe
B. passwd -u joe
C. useradd -s /bin/bash joe
D. chage -E -1 joe
A is correct. Joe's account has an incorrect associated shell so using "usermod -s /bin/bash joe" sets a valid shell.
